title: Jean-Marie Le Pen, who put the far right back at the heart of French politics, has died
summary: From his election as France's youngest MP in 1956 to his daughter Marine Le Pen taking the party he founded to new heights, Jean-Marie Le Pen was present at every stage of the French far right's post-war history. He died on Tuesday, January 7, at the age of 96.

title: France remembers 'Charlie Hebdo' attacks 10 years on
summary: Commemorations were held on the 10th anniversary of the attack against the satirical newspaper. Twelve people died in the attacks, including eight of its staff.

title: The 'Charlie Hebdo' and Hyper Casher attacks: Three days of blood, terror and tears
summary: From the offices of the satirical newspaper to a kosher supermarket, this is the story of the attacks of January 7-9, 2015, and the hunt for their perpetrators, the brothers Saïd and Chérif Kouachi and Amedy Coulibaly.

title: Trump refuses to rule out use of military force to take control of Greenland and the Panama Canal
summary: Less than two weeks before he takes office, US President-elect Donald Trump has left open the use of the US military to take control of Greenland and the Panama Canal.

title: Jimmy Carter eulogized by Kamala Harris, congressional leaders at US Capitol
summary: Special Air Mission 39 departed Atlanta with Carter's remains on Tuesday morning and arrived at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland. Before takeoff, eight military pallbearers held Carter's casket as canons fired on the tarmac nearby. The scene repeated outside Washington as the former president's casket was removed from the plane.

title: Trial of 2020 attack on former 'Charlie Hebdo' offices: 'I saw myself as an animal with big teeth covered in blood'
summary: Zaheer Mahmoud, the Pakistani migrant who stabbed two people on September 25, 2020, in revenge for Prophet Mohammed cartoons published in 'Charlie Hebdo,' asked his victims for 'forgiveness' in court.

title: Deschamps to step down as France coach after 2026 World Cup
summary:
The 56-year-old has already set the record for longest-serving official France coach.
According to media reports, he will officially announce his decision to leave the job in an interview with Brigitte Macron on French television on Wednesday.

title: Many structures already destroyed in Pacific Palisades wildfire, California governor says
summary: The erratic weather caused President Joe Biden to cancel plans to travel to inland Riverside County, California, where he was to announce the establishment of two new national monuments in the state. Nearly 26,000 people in more than 10,000 households and more than 13,000 structures are under threat from the blaze, said the LA fire chief.

title: Russian authorities' handling of Black Sea oil spill criticized: 'It's the worst-case scenario.'
summary: In southwestern Russia, thousands of volunteers are cleaning up the beaches polluted by the sinking of two oil tankers in the Black Sea on December 15, 2024. But scientists and NGOs consider the resources and equipment deployed to be insufficient.

title: Israel worried about lawsuits abroad against its soldiers
summary: An Israeli soldier on vacation in Brazil had to flee the country following a complaint regarding war crimes committed in Gaza.

title: Over 100 people killed in Tibet after strong earthquake
summary: A devastating earthquake struck China's remote Tibet region on Tuesday, killing at least 126 people. China recorded the magnitude as 6.8.

title: Meta announces end to its fact-checking program in the US
summary: Echoing Republican complaints about fact-checking programs, Meta's founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced a major rollback of its content moderation policies, amid moves to reconcile with Donald Trump.

title: US says Sudan's RSF committed 'genocide' in Darfur, sanctions leader
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced sanctions against RSF leader Mohammed Hamdan Dagalo, known as Hemedti, for his 'role in systematic atrocities committed against the Sudanese people.'

title: NASA proposes cheaper, quicker way to get Mars rocks and soil to Earth
summary: NASA is weighing options to ensure samples collected by its Perseverance rover arrive on Earth in the 2030s, well ahead of astronauts venturing to the red planet.

title: Trump announces $20 billion Emirati investment in US data centers
summary: Donald Trump has announced a multi-billion dollar investment in US data centers by UAE firm DAMAC Properties as the infrastructure needs of the AI sector grow.

title: Justin Trudeau's resignation: 'Canada's prime minister faces growing unpopularity after nine years in power'
summary: The leader of the Liberal Party, in power since 2015, announced his forthcoming resignation from his role as party leader and from his duties as head of government. Geneviève Tellier, professor of social science at the University of Ottawa, looks back at the reasons that forced him to make this choice.

title: Algeria slams French 'interference' over jailing of writer
summary: Algeria has accused France of 'unacceptable interference' after President Macron commented on the jailing of a dissident French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal.

title: Chad says France's Macron 'in the wrong era' over comments to African countries
summary: In a speech to France's diplomatic corps on Monday, Macron accused African leaders of 'forgetting' to 'thank' France for preventing their nations from falling under the control of jihadist insurgencies.

title: 'One Hundred Years of Solitude' on Netflix: A picture book for Gabriel García Márquez
summary: Reverently transposed to the screen, the Colombian Nobel Prize winner's masterpiece finds its settings and performers, but loses its magic.

title: 'I lost brothers that morning': In front of the former 'Charlie Hebdo' premises and the Hyper Cacher, a tribute to the victims and their families
summary: The day of commemoration of the January 7, 2015 attacks took place in a secure atmosphere, with the public kept at a distance from the various ceremonial sites.

title: In South Korea, YouTube channels are exacerbating the political crisis
summary: Since the proclamation of martial law by President Yoon Suk Yeol and the arrest warrant targeting him, demonstrations by his supporters and opponents have been fanned by popular YouTube channels, unscrupulously resorting to misinformation.

title: Cartoon in tribute to 'Charlie Hebdo': 'Without humor we're all dead'
summary: Le Monde and Cartooning for Peace pay tribute to Charlie Hebdo on the tenth anniversary of the attacks against the satirical newspaper. Today, we publish the French cartoonist Chappatte.

title: Faced with Elon Musk and his meddling, Europeans are disunited
summary: While French President Emmanuel Macron has accused the X boss of supporting 'reactionary international news,' Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has so far remained silent.

title: 'Dear Charlie': The letters readers sent to the magazine after the January 7, 2015 attack
summary: After the massacre, 'Charlie Hebdo' received tens of thousands of letters, preserved in the Paris Archives, which Le Monde was able to consult. They include many children's drawings sent by teachers and parents, and often moving messages of support from adults.

title: Japanese Love Hotels as seen by François Prost: Kitsch and popular refuges
summary: Continuing his inventory of the facades of places of pleasure around the world, photographer François Prost traveled across Japan in search of 'rabuhos,' those flashy love hotels.

title: 'To stay at the top of global technology, Nvidia sets a new horizon: robotics'
summary: Head of the microchip giant Jensen Huang announced his intention to enter the field of humanoid robots and autonomous cars at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

title: The uncertain consequences of Jean-Marie Le Pen's death
summary: The death of the French far right's former leader comes with political questions for his daughter Marine Le Pen. Should his funeral be public? How should she speak of him?

title: Agence France-Presse, a prime target for the KGB
summary: 'Cold War moles' (Part 5/5). Between 1956 and 1982, the Soviet intelligence agency recruited six AFP journalists as agents.

title: Donald Trump's rhetoric of a new American imperialism
summary: At a press conference in Florida on Tuesday, the president-elect reiterated his territorial ambitions, wanting to gain control of the Panama Canal, Canada and Greenland.

title: 'At what point does hybrid warfare become outright war?'
summary: Alongside its war in Ukraine, Russia is engaging in another form of conflict, increasingly intense, against the rest of Europe. Europeans are lacking a strategy to deal with it, writes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: Iran rejects Macron's remarks on its role in region as 'baseless'
summary: The French president had said in a speech Monday that Iran is the 'main strategic and security challenge for France, Europeans, the entire region and beyond,' a claim Tehran said was 'baseless.'

title: From Chad to Senegal, Macron's remarks on 'ingratitude' of African leaders spark backlash
summary: In a speech to French ambassadors, French president Emmanuel Macron claimed that African leaders 'forgot to say thank you' for France's 2013 military intervention in the Sahel, provoking immediate ire from Chad's president.

title: Telegram gave more user data to French authorities after founder's arrest
summary: Pavel Durov, the founder and chief executive officer of the messaging app, was arrested in Paris last August over criminal content posted by users on his platform.

title: Meta's Zuckerberg follows Musk and Bezos in Big Tech's march behind Trump
summary: Mark Zuckerberg's announcement on Tuesday of changes to the content moderation policy of Facebook and Instagram marks a symbolic U-turn. He says his move is in the name of 'freedom of expression.'

title: France urges EU Commission to stand firm against Musk's interference
summary: Echoing Macron's Monday accusation that tech billionaire Elon Musk was interfering in elections, French Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot called on the European Commission to be firm in applying laws against such moves.

title: Italy announces journalist freed from imprisonment in Iran
summary: Cecilia Sala, an Italian journalist who had been arrested in Tehran and jailed for three weeks, was freed and sent back to Italy, according to a statement by Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's office.

title: French politicians react to death of far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen
summary: The co-founder of the far-right Front National party died on Tuesday, January 7.

title: Tibet earthquake: 'In the worst-hit villages, 80-90% of houses have collapsed'
summary: A magnitude 6.8 earthquake killed at least 126 people and injured 188 in the south of the autonomous region in China, close to Nepal, on Tuesday morning. Rescue workers are still searching the rubble.
